Review of linear transformations from Lecture 6

Reflections across lines $y = mx$
Reflect $e_1, e_2$ into $T(e_1), T(e_2)$, and let $A = \matrixstart T(e_1) & T(e_2) \matrixend$
We find a vector orthogonal to $y = mx = x \matrixstart 1 \\ m \matrixend$; namely, $\matrixstart -m \\ 1 \matrixend$
Then we let $e_1 = a \matrixstart 1 \\ m \matrixend + b \matrixstart -m \\ 1 \matrixend$ and use dot-products to pull out $a,b$
Finally, $T(e_1) = a \matrixstart 1 \\ m \matrixend - b \matrixstart -m \\ 1 \matrixend$ and $T(e_2)$ follows similarly
See worksheet $7$

Then matrix multiplication and inversion

Motivation: composition of linear functions $g(f(x)) = (g \circ f)(x)$

Then we have $T = Ax$ mapping $\mathbb{R}^m \to \mathbb{R}^n$, $S = Bx$ mapping $\mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^o$
So $A$ is $n \times m$, $B$ is $o \times n$

Consider $S(T(x)) = (S \circ T)(x) = B(Ax)$
